sentences: Matthias Paul (German pronunciation: [maˈtiːas ˈpaʊ̯l]; born 16 December 1971), known professionally as Paul van Dyk (German: [ˈpaʊ̯l fan ˈdʏk]) is a German DJ, record producer and musician.
section: N/A

sentences: One of the first true renowned DJs, van Dyk was the first artist to receive a Grammy Award nomination in the newly added category of Best Dance/Electronic album for his 2003 release Reflections.
section: N/A

sentences: He was named the World's number one DJ in both 2005 and 2006, something few DJs have ever achieved.
section: N/A

sentences: He was the first ever DJ to be named number one by Mixmag in 2005.
section: N/A

sentences: By 2008, he had sold over 3 million albums worldwide.
section: N/A

sentences: A trance producer starting in the early 1990s, van Dyk quickly achieved popularity with his remix of "Love Stimulation" by Humate on the record label MFS in 1993 and with his hit single "For an Angel".
section: N/A

sentences: He still is an avid trance lover to this day.
section: N/A

sentences: Van Dyk is currently the radio host of "Vonyc Sessions with Paul" on Dash Radio.
section: N/A

== Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: Paul van Dyk grew up in East Berlin in a single parent household; his father left him and his mother when he was four years old.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: While living there, he worked as a broadcast technician and began training to become a carpenter.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: Paul van Dyk claims his musical education came from radio.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: Where he grew up there were no record stores at which to buy music, so he kept in touch with the world beyond the Berlin Wall by secretly listening to the popular but forbidden Western radio stations RIAS (Radio in the American Sector) and SFB and mixtapes occasionally smuggled into the country and copied among school friends.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: The first album he acquired was Organisation by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (OMD), of which he said, "It was extremely influential.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: Early electronic, but also melodies and poppy elements, the general imprint of what later came for me in music.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: "Shortly before the fall of the Berlin Wall, van Dyk and his mother were given permission to leave East Germany and moved to Hamburg to live with his aunt.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: In 1990, van Dyk moved back to Berlin.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: His first appearance as a DJ was in the club Tresor in March 1991.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: After several more dates, he was given the chance to perform at Andre'Hoche's (1991–1993) Dubmission parties in the Turbine club, together with the young resident DJ Kid Paul.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: With Cosmic Baby, he collaborated as The Visions of Shiva.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: Their single "Perfect Day" was released by the Berlin independent label MFS (Masterminded For Success) Records, run by English expatriate producer Mark Reeder and manager Torsten Jurk.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: In February 1993, van Dyk and Kid Paul hosted an installment of the weekly three-hour "HR3 Clubnight" radio show, performing for a nationwide audience on German radio.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: The second and final Visions of Shiva single "How Much Can You Take?" was released, and van Dyk and Cosmic went their separate musical ways.
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: By late summer, Paul released his first DJ-mix compilation "X-Mix-1 – the MFS Trip" and remixed Humate's trance hymn "Love Stimulation".
section: == Early life and career == | === Early life and musical beginning ===

sentences: Meanwhile, MFS acquired many remixes for Paul.

sentences: He recorded his debut LP 45 RPM with Johnny Klimek and VOOV.

sentences: Seven Ways established van Dyk as a trance pioneer and was van Dyk's first real success in Britain.

sentences: Seven Ways was voted the No. 1 album by readers of DJ Magazine.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: In early 1997, van Dyk began collaborating with U.S. music producer BT.

sentences: Together, they produced tracks such as "Flaming June", "Forbidden Fruit" and "Namistai".
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: The singles "Forbidden Fruit" and "Beautiful Place" did not cause a great impact at first but, with the release of Seven Ways and "Words" appearing at the height of the British superclub phenomenon, van Dyk's own material began to attract attention.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: "By the time they realised I was a German, it was too late!"

sentences: Van Dyk also remixed a well-known early-1990s track, "The Age of Love", in 1997.

sentences: In 1998, 45 RPM was re-released in the UK and in the US.

sentences: To mark the event, and in homage to the defunct E-Werk, van Dyk released a remix of "For An Angel".
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: Van Dyk took up a residency at Sheffield's Gatecrasher and declared himself anti-drugs, which led to home-made "No E, Pure PvD" T-shirts, also a sly note to journalists that his surname contained no "E".
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: In 1998, Paul remixed Matt Laws/Binary Finary's famous "1998" single, which was a successful version that took Binary Finary to the top of the German Dance charts.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: In mid-1998, van Dyk left MFS Records and took a controlling share in the new label Vandit Records.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: In 2000, van Dyk flexed his skills with his melodic, dancefloor-friendly Out There and Back, which included the hit single "Tell Me Why (The Riddle)", a collaboration with Saint Etienne.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: It also included the European hit We Are Alive, a remixed version of the Jennifer Brown song Alive.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: His first mix album The Politics of Dancing (2001) was followed by a world tour and a DVD release Global (2003) and the Mexican film Zurdo, for which van Dyk composed the soundtrack and won a Mexican Oscar for his work.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: Reflections (2003) inspired by van Dyk's trips to India, was a more melancholy affair, and includes the single "Nothing But You", a collaboration with Hemstock & Jennings.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: It was nominated for a Grammy in the category of Best Electronic Album.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: The same song was also used on the soundtrack of the game FIFA 2004.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: The mix album The Politics of Dancing 2 (2005) was preceded by a single "The Other Side," featuring Wayne Jackson; a song dedicated to the victims, and their families, of the Sumatra-Andaman earthquake and the subsequent tsunami that struck Thailand on 26 December 2004.
section: == Early life and career == | === 1994–2007: 45 RPM, Seven Ways, Out There and Back & Reflections ===

sentences: His original productions from Reflections have been synced into major motion pictures such as Into the Blue, Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants, television's Entertainment Tonight and MTV Cribs, and international ad campaigns for Motorola, HBO, Land Rover, Ski Vail and most recently for Jeep.

sentences: In Between ===
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: Van Dyk released his fifth studio album, In Between, worldwide on 14 August 2007.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: The album, which he created over a three-year period, debuted at number No. 115 on the Billboard 200 and No. 2 on the Billboard's Top Electronic Albums and No. 1 on the Top Heatseekers.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: The album also reached No. 16 on the Mexican Albums Chart and No. 5 on the Mexican International Chart.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: The album was released accompanied by a special edition limited to two thousand copies which included a mixed version of the full album, along with an eight-track bonus CD and an eight-page photo anthology.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: The album was produced primarily by Paul van Dyk himself, and features a wide range of collaborators including David Byrne of Talking Heads, Jessica Sutta of the Pussycat Dolls, Ashley Tomberlin from Luminary, Alex M.O.R.P.H, Lo Fi Sugar, Rea Garvey of Reamonn, Ryan Merchant and Wayne Jackson.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: It also features a vocal sample from Ben Lost from Probspot's "Blows My Mind" on the song "Another Sunday".
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: In June 2007, van Dyk embarked on the worldwide "In Between Tour" to promote the album.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: Van Dyk's work with EA Games has resulted in multiple releases featuring his music on Mirror's Edge, Need for Speed: Underground 2, and Grand Slam Tennis out in 2009.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: The song was released on the film's soundtrack, and helped the album win a Grammy Award that Paul van Dyk shares with his collaborators.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: He has also remixed Depeche Mode's "Martyr", Justin Timberlake's "What Goes Around...
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: Comes Around" and Britney Spears' "Gimme More".
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: In May 2008, van Dyk set up a remix competition with digital download network Beatport, inviting aspiring producers to remix his single 'Far Away' which appeared on his album In Between.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: On 9 November 2009, van Dyk performed alongside Northern Ireland vocalist Johnny McDaid at the Berlin Wall 20th Anniversary Memorial.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: They recorded and performed a song for the event called 'We Are One'.;
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: A dance music event, called 'We Are One Festival', was organized at the O2 World Berlin, named after the song he collaborated with Johnny McDaid on for the Berlin Wall Anniversary.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: Some artists who performed included Armin van Buuren, Underworld and Blueman Group.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2007–2010: In Between ===

sentences: In 2010, it was revealed that van Dyk's record label Vandit would be merging with Armin van Buuren's Armada Music.

section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: The album features vocals from Johnny McDaid of Snow Patrol, Plumb, Sarah Howells and various other artists.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: This release was followed by The Politics of Dancing 3, which van Dyk put out on 4 May 2015.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: With its release, the series, which began in 2001, moved from that of music compilation to artist album.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: On it, van Dyk worked with artists including Aly & Fila, Giuseppe Ottaviani and others.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: On 28 February 2016 during the A State of Trance Festival in Utrecht, van Dyk fell through a concealed gap in the stage during his performance, and was transported to a local hospital.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Due to a spinal injury and severe brain injury, van Dyk remained under doctors' supervision at Utrecht Medical Center for weeks.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: He was cleared for professional medical transfer to a facility in Berlin until mid-May 2016.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Numerous performances suffered forced cancellations during this time, including the Electric Daisy Carnival Mexico.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Van Dyk began a light touring schedule mid-June 2016, including Electric Daisy Carnival in Las Vegas, Cream at Amnesia in Ibiza, and Luminosity Festival in the Netherlands.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Van Dyk's accident forced a significant delay in the recording of his eighth studio album.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Having continued to convalesce, van Dyk was able to complete the album in the early summer of 2017.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: From Then On was released on 20 October of the same year through his own Vandit label.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Subsequently, van Dyk drew on the experiences of the preceding year, which were most clearly evidenced in the track's titles.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: It received positive feedback from the press, with Billboard calling it "a celebration of a beautiful life."
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: and the website EDMSauce describing it as "near flawless."
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

sentences: Musically the album continued in largely the same artistic vein as ‘The Politics Of Dancing 3’ and included cooperations with – amongst others – Alex M.O.R.P.H., M.I.K.E. Push and Jordan Suckley.
section: == Early life and career == | === 2012–present: Evolution, The Politics of Dancing 3 and From Then On ===

== Politics ==

sentences: Politics ==
section: == Politics ==

sentences: Since 2001, van Dyk has taken an interest in politics.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: His creation of The Politics of Dancing compilation was inspired by electronic dance music's universal acclaim by different people around the world.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: "Palestinians are dancing with Israelis.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: Lebanese people are dancing with Israelis – without war, without anything in their minds other than treating each other respectfully", said van Dyk in 2006.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: He also has called EDM "a political and diplomatic tool that could be used."
section: == Politics ==

sentences: Having grown up with little freedom, his musical career has helped him voice his opinions about politics.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: He opposes the Iraq War and the War in Afghanistan.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: He describes himself as anti-war and has advertised this while performing, by wearing a shirt reading "Make peace, not war".
section: == Politics ==

sentences: Van Dyk has helped fight poverty by supporting social programs to help disadvantaged people in India, New York, and Berlin.
section: == Politics ==

sentences: He also participated in Rock the Vote in 2004 and 2008; he and Bono being the only non-American artists to join the campaign encouraging young people to vote.
section: == Politics ==
